metadata.case_name: Zafar Ali and others v. Custodian of Evacuee Property

facts.text: Khadim Ali died on or about October 1, 1950, leaving three sons (Nusrat Ali, Fateh Ali, Zafar Ali) and five daughters, who became entitled to two houses in certain shares.
Khadim Ali had never been declared an evacuee.

In September 1951, two notices issued under s.7 of Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950 to Nusrat Ali and Fateh Ali requiring them to show cause why they should not be declared evacuees and houses evacuee property.
Neither Nusrat Ali nor Fateh Ali appeared.
On January 10, 1952, Custodian declared Nusrat Ali and Fateh Ali evacuees and houses evacuee property under s.7.
Upon declaration, houses vested in Custodian under s.8 and he took possession.
Petitioners are Zafar Ali (other son) and two daughters of Khadim Ali. No notice under s.7 issued to them at any time, never declared evacuees.

Petitioners had no knowledge of proceedings for a long time; upon knowledge, took steps including appeal by male petitioner (Zafar Ali) on behalf of all to Custodian-General against order of January 10, 1952, which was rejected.
These facts are not in dispute.
Zafar Ali claims father left a will giving him larger share than on intestacy.
Properties acquired under Displaced Persons (Compensation and Rehabilitation) Act, 1954; notification under s.12(1) issued.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Custodian was entitled to declare the entirety of the two houses evacuee property and deprive the petitioners of their rights in them.
Whether Zafar Ali is bound by the order dismissing his appeal to Custodian-General as time-barred.
Whether rights of petitioners affected by acquisition under Displaced Persons (Compensation and Rehabilitation) Act, 1954.

petitioner_arguments.text: Petitioners wrongly deprived of rights in houses; no notice under s.7 issued to them, so their interest could not vest in Custodian.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950 s.7; Ebrahim Aboobaker v. Tek Chand Dolwani

petitioner_arguments.text: Appeal to Custodian-General does not bind them as Zafar Ali not party to original proceedings.

respondent_arguments.text: Concedes that female petitioners' interest could not be affected by order under s.7.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950 s.7

respondent_arguments.text: Zafar Ali bound by dismissal of his appeal to Custodian-General as quasi-judicial decision.
Properties acquired under Displaced Persons (Compensation and Rehabilitation) Act, 1954 s.12(2), extinguishing evacuee rights.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Displaced Persons (Compensation and Rehabilitation) Act, 1954 s.12(2)

court_reasoning.text: No property of any person can be declared evacuee property unless that person given notice under s.7.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Admittedly no such notice to petitioners; their interest could not vest in Custodian.

court_reasoning.text: Zafar Ali not party to original proceeding; no appeal lay or necessary; dismissed as time-barred, no judicial determination of his rights.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Order of January 10, 1952 without jurisdiction as to Zafar Ali's share; appeal does not change that.

court_reasoning.text: s.12(2) of 1954 Act extinguishes rights of evacuee only; petitioners not evacuees.
Not concerned with Zafar Ali's claim under will.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Says nothing about rights under will, if any.

holdings.text: As no notice under s.7 to petitioners, their interest in houses never vested in Custodian; acts depriving them of property cannot be upheld.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ebrahim Aboobaker v. Tek Chand Dolwani
precedents_cited.relevance: Well established that no property can be declared evacuee unless person given notice under s.7.

statutes_cited.name: Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950
statutes_cited.relevance: Notice under s.7 required before declaration of evacuee; vesting under s.8 upon declaration.

statutes_cited.name: Displaced Persons (Compensation and Rehabilitation) Act, 1954
statutes_cited.relevance: Extinguishes right, title and interest of evacuee in evacuee property upon notification; does not affect non-evacuees.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Violation of fundamental right to hold property under Art.19(1)(f); petition under Art.32.

outcome.summary: Petition allowed; order of January 10, 1952 set aside insofar as it affected rights of petitioners in the properties concerned.
outcome.relief_granted: Set aside order of January 10, 1952 insofar as petitioners' rights.

key_quotes.text: "It is well established and not disputed, that no property of any person can be declared to be evacuee property unless that person had first been given a notice under s.7 of the Act."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core legal principle applied to petitioners' case.

key_quotes.text: "Their interest in the houses, therefore, could not have vested in the Custodian."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Direct holding on vesting invalid without notice.
